ratings so one of this is one of the major improvements with version 200 of
HDT print and onwards is I've used a fuzzy logic based method for picking the
best match uh previously it used to be a score oriented method the highest score always wins and you know sometimes you
have two scores very close together say 126 and 125 now which of the two might be the
winner well it was very hard to say and sometimes if you if you're dealing with
obfuscated servers they might be different server families but with confidence ratings we're able to easily
tell U we don't look at so we don't look at the total scores anymore we just look at the percentage of confidence ratings
uh confidence ratings also allow us to identify false positives um one of the
things with htd print or for that matter any fingerprinting tool is these tools
will always will only recognize those those signatures which are present in
its database like if the tool knows of only three web servers whatever server
it's run against it's only going to report you one of three if it's a totally unknown P server you can't
expect it to say come up and say okay this this is an unknown fourth server
however with confidence ratings you can get pretty close to identifying if a
particular server signature is not present within the your set of signatures let's just say you ran HTT
print HTT print only knows of Apache and IIs and you ran HTT print against
Netscape Enterprise server and HTT print reports this is an IIs server it's it's
of course false but then if you look at the confidence rating it'll have a very dismal confidence rating say something
like 10% or 15% as opposed to the 80s or 90% confidence ratings so when you look
at that and you find out that the confidence rating is too low you you you'll have to think saying okay why
what what is it that caused this confidence rating is too low is it a part of my signature database no okay
let's add it in there then when you run it again confidence ratings are going to go up

to present you a completely different concept fingerprinting is all dealing
with HTTP headers and HTTP Behavior what we want to now look at
especially when build building automated tools for assessment is the content that gets returned the HTML content U
especially we want to look at customized error Pages you know you have for particular Behavior instead of a 404
you're getting a 3001 3002 redirect some servers also return 200 okay uh what
happens is because HTTP so customizable we cannot really rely on the server's
response codes you can easily build a server which returns 200 okay for every
even even in the case of 404 and then try running ncto against it it'll show you every vulnerability under the sun
lighting up then then how do you determine what's present and what's not uh in fact the developer of ncto
emailed me two weeks ago he wants he wants some of this fingerprinting
technology to be built I'm I'm going to see and see if he can cooperate and come up with a really powerful tool um
but so therefore to overcome this customized error problem and customized Response Code problem we now know that
we can't trust the code number that's coming back we can't really trust the 200 okay or stuff that's coming back so
how do we make sense of what's a valid page that's got returned and what's an error and for that I present to you the
concept of page signatures so for every HTML that's received back we derive
what's called a page signature the objective here is to accurately identify
proper HTTP response codes and responses we want to minimize false positives of
course it greatly helps in automated testing and again the fun stuff is you
know when you're applying these theories to solve a particular problem you always get these nice side effects so one of
the side effects that I derive out of paid signatures and quite a few actually to or three is we can extend page
signatures Beyond error detection on one of the things we can do is to figure out
uh group uh group different Resources by functionality like for example if you
have a website which is template driven you have you know one CGI or PHP that is
generating all these pages with different data P page signatures are totally oblivious to the data in there
they just care about they will return the same page signature for all similar
looking Pages page signatures solve the problem of whether this page
is similar to this page so I mean sure they both have a grid of gray blobs on
it the words may be different but the this page and this page look
similar this page and this page does not look similar this page has thick black bars and lines but this page is similar
to this page so this is what page signatures will tell you and you know if you have crawled a huge website and you
have all these HTML you can run page signatures and they'll group these Pages for you saying okay these 30 pages came
from these 30 pages actually have the same page signature so therefore you can say oh they got generated from one
particular Source more about that a little later let me dive into page signatures per se um each P each HTTP
response therefore has a page signature it's completely independent of the content absolutely again no string
Compares done nothing inside and I don't care about what's in there it has
ability to overlook random content to a certain degree just by the way that it's
designed um all page signatures are constant in length they are 32 bytes as
shown Below in the blue bar along with three bytes extra for the actual Response Code that was received not that
it matters but I'm just throwing these two together uh computation time for each page signature is order of n where
n is the bytes of HTML that got returned and comparison time because there constant in length is constant so it's a
very very efficient way of analyzing uh you know of doing analysis on the fly
with automated testing so over here is and I'll give
